142438586.review:
Oh. My. God. Where do I start...

INSIDE is a great and coherent game with lots of well-designed puzzles and, let's call them, "action segments."

The difficulty is just right for this type of game. Sometimes it can be challenging and make you pause for a moment, but usually, the solutions are easy (and fun!) to find.

The movement of the main character is well-executed and really comfortable.

The world-building deserves separate praise. It has everything you need to fully immerse yourself in the game. Amazing ambiance? Yes. Almost seamless transitions between locations? You got it! Things happening in the background? Absolutely!

Honestly, I don't know if I can say anything negative about it.
In conclusion - GO AND PLAY IT RIGHT NOW!

142244681.review:
The game's message, in my opinion, is that you cannot defeat the system, no matter what you do or how hard you try. When you actually escape, you die and realize that they led you there; even your false escape was part of their plan (see the miniature forest you are falling into in the lab, foreshadowing the ending). Even when you turn into that creature that annihilates everything that appears to be beyond their control, in reality you are part of their plan.

In other words, you're always INSIDE some larger system or structure, no matter how free you think you are.

Weirdly Beautiful! Inside is one of the most beautiful and subtly detailed 2D platformer games i've ever played. Every frame of the game is meticulously crafted and feels cinematic to look at.

| SPOILER
| At its core, Inside is a story about a boy who breaks into a facility where Scientists Experiment on What they 
| call "The Huddle". The story progresses as the boy goes through the facility to find out whats going in there, | | and eventually end up rescuing the Huddle in the End. The deep meanings are left to you to interpret.

The Environment, The Lighting and The Atmosphere all sets you up for a gripping experience right from the start. The encounters in the game are so good that you always escape them at the last moment. Yes you obviously die sometimes, just to understand how the mechanics work. 

Might play again, for the Alternate Ending!

142044381.review:
This was a phenomenal experience. Dark, unsettling, grotesque, tense. This game wants to make you feel a lot of different things. The graphics are beautiful and go a long ways for setting the tone of the game, especially when paired with great sound design and minimalist OST. Gameplay is simple in concept, but changes enough to keep things interesting and to keep you from rushing through it too quickly. However, above all this game wins on the merits of its mood, and it doesn't get so bogged down with tedious gameplay that the mood is ruined. 

I honestly don't have much negative to say about this game. It's roughly the appropriate length for a game like this, though I've yet to compare it to this dev's other titles. And it checks out on about every other metric I'd measure its success on.

Tl;dr - If you want a good puzzle-platformer with a disturbing narrative and polished presentation, this is an excellent choice for you.

141705602.review: This game is nothing short of a masterpiece. As with its predecessor Limbo by the same studio it contains ingenious puzzles, traps, and dangerous encounters against the backdrop of an even more beautiful scenery than Limbo. While I love Limbo in all its aspects, this game has an added depth that Limbo's missing. The atmosphere and ambience, the minimalist and suggestive brutalistic architectural world the player moves around in is sublime, the art direction is quite awesome and perfect, making this one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen and played. Many times I just walked back and forth just to admire the world around me. It's the weirdest thing too; as I progressed in the game I felt that although the world is quite the scary place to walk around in I at the same time felt a longing to go there, like I had some kind of connection to it. It felt very northen and seeing as I'm a swede I found many things eerily familiar, and the reason for this as it turned out in the end when the credits rolled I found that the studio behind the game, Playdead, is danish. No wonder I seemed to feel at home in certain aspects when playing this game; they've perfectly incorporated the visual sense of the northen scenery and then added their magic to it. They really managed to bring about the atmospheric melancholy of the northen people and I absolutely loved everything about it. The world is indeed cold and oppressively scary but it is really beautiful. Many times I just sat and looked at the visuals in complete fascination. My hat off to the studio for making this gem of a masterpiece. Please continue creating awesome games.

141220419.review: I played Inside first and then Limbo. I feel that the difficulty level of Limbo is much harder than Inside. The story of Limbo and Inside have similarities and differences. In both games, we play a silent and nameless protagonist who we do not know much about even after we have completed the games. Both games use environmental storytelling to allow the player to experience the game and the story that they intend to convey without the use of any spoken language. Both games provoke more questions than answers. In both games, we start off in the forest. In Inside, we get chased by both dogs and human beings who want to capture the player character. We are left wondering why did other humans want to capture the player character. Who are we playing as and what are we doing in the game? Where are we? As the game progresses, we observe strange happenings in the game world as we can see mind controlled animals such as pigs and other human beings which our player character can mind control using a cap that he wears on his head. [spoiler] Later, after a strange incident where our player character is drowned by a mermaid creature, our player character gains the ability to breathe underwater permanently and also can mind control other human beings effortlessly without the use of a mind control cap. [/spoiler] Why is our player character able to mind control other creatures and human beings? What does this mind control ability symbolize? What are those other human beings who move like zombies in the game world and who do they symbolize or represent? I feel that Inside is less disturbing than Limbo though because there is more "humanity" in the other humanoid creatures found in the game world. In Limbo most of the other human like creatures want to kill the player character except for one - the female character whom the player character gets to meet at the end of the game. In Inside, the player character can get many other humanoids to help him progress the game by mind controlling them. In Limbo, the player character is very much on his own, which exacerbates the feeling of loneliness when we, the player controls him to overcome the puzzles and challenges in the game world. In Inside, we can feel that our player character gets more powerful as the game progresses due to the abilities he gains while playing the game but in Limbo, the player character practically remains very much the same throughout the game, which gives us the perception that Limbo is a much more difficult game than Inside. Both games also have an open-ended ending which leaves the players wondering what happened at the end of the game. In fact, there is no closure.

The constant simplistic, yet ominous view of what's on screen, the phenomenal sound design that really did not have to be this good and the ambiguity of the story are what easily makes this game for me a 10/10. 140640267.review:
9 / 10

A short but very enjoyable, imaginative, atmospheric 2.5D puzzle-platformer.

INSIDE is a title with a very dark and somber atmospheric feel - CONTROL-like even. It takes place in an enormous secret government facility of unknown purpose that almost seems to consume you as you progress. The game has an overall unsettling theme throughout and uses dramatic lighting and audio to fantastic effect. And it only gets better and more imaginative as you progress further into the story.

INSIDE starts a little on the slow side, but quickly gains traction. The game has a simple, pleasant art-style with a very high level of attention to detail especially where it comes to environmental interactions. The animations are supremely smooth and thought-out overall.

It's a little on the short side overall, and not very challenging. But it is quite a trip and a worthwhile playthrough.

140515412.review:
Inside is a fairly well put together puzzle game with a phenomenal art style and an interesting premise. 

The Good: 
- Core Design: The puzzles are excellent. With a decent, diegetic tutorial of the mechanics you're expected to use and the removal of objects that should follow patterns, but do not, the puzzles themselves are practically flawless.
- Difficulty: Difficulty in games comes from them being 1 or a combination of 3 things: challenging, punishing, and bad. Inside is not hugely challenging, and not punishing at all. It's more or less about the difficulty a game like this should be. 

The Bad:
- Tutorialisation: Inside lacks tutorials, which is mostly not a real problem because there aren't too many mechanics but does get frustrating. The designers need to learn the difference between "not holding the player's hand" and "not telling the player what the world is capable of or what is expected of them". There is no tutorial, there is mostly no demonstration of mechanics (you're just expected to already know what they are and how to use them). It's the difference between tough-love and parental neglect. You are put into puzzles that I'm sure the solutions of are obvious to the designers, but are obtuse and arbitrary to a player. 
- Gameplay: The movement is not good. No, it's not an action combat game or a tight platformer where the ability to control the minute movements of your character is essential to being any good at the game, but the kid is awful to control. He's simultaneously floaty and heavy, it's like controlling a balloon filled half-and-half with water and air. Most of this problem could be fixed by just making him stop more quickly, but maybe that's a stylistic decision, maybe they really wanted to make you so irritated with this child that you aren't even disappointed when he gets eaten by dogs, who knows? But there is also several sections where you could really stand to benefit from being able to control him more precisely: there's some sections where the timing is quite tight, and making a small mistake risks an immediate death, but he doesn't control well enough to so you WILL die until you can do it perfectly, which just takes you out of the game's world and frustrates you (I'm talking about that last mermaid section).

The Rest:
I don't really think there's a 'story', per se, because there is never any explanation as to why the things that are happening are happening, nor much environmental storytelling to explain what's going on, why, or how. Absolutely nothing about the scenario is explained, and that's a weakness for someone like me because I quite like games with a plot, and it's a great shame because the plot could have been fantastic if they'd put as much effort into it as they put into the jiggle physics of the blob at the end of the game.

Conclusion:
Yeah, it's pretty good. Worth a play, but don't expect it to play very well.

139977240.review:
[h1] Why you should or should not play INSIDE [/h1]

[b] What is INSIDE? [/b]

INSIDE is a side view story game where you go through different obstacles to make your way through the story. It is more horror themed and makes you kind of question things during the story. It is psychological horror mostly, and some of the puzzles that you will experience will be so anxiety inducing that you may or may not pi$$ yourself. 

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"Okay, okay cool controls."
-"OMG PIGGIES AND ANIMALS YAY"
-"oh no...."

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

This game has very basic controls, though if you are not ready for a intense psychological horror with a lot gore and death. (So if you are sensitive to that I would not recommend this game for you as a beginner game.) If you are into the psychological horror in movies and such then this game may be for you! It definitely has an intense story. THOUGH some parts are kind of mentally challenging to get through and the puzzles can be very confusing at times, so if you are not ready to be mentally challenged then maybe this game is not beginner friendly for you.

[b] Game Play: [/b]

The game play involves a side view of your character and loads of puzzles you have to get through as you consistently move forward to reach your destination. You don't really fight anyone or thing and its more you run away a lot of the time. You do have to swim, climb, jump, and bolt your way through this story in order to stay alive and get to the end.

[b] Graphics: [/b]

The graphics are really interesting, as you will notice right away none of the characters have any faces really. It makes for an interesting plot line. The graphics are beautiful but still maintain pretty simple. This game will not run your computer/console to the ground if you play it for hours on end so that is also cool!

[b] Community: [/b]

There is not much of a community, though the steam community for this game seem pretty friendly and have loads of helpful guides for the game!

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

The story itself is around 3 hours long, maybe 4 at most, then if you would like to achievement hunt it may take you a little longer. Realistically you can play as many times as you want and for as long as you want.

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

In my opinion this game is really nice if you want a quick story horror game. Though it may not be good if you want a game that will make you go into the 100+ hours and meet people and such. 

[i] Any edits that are made with this review will be added here: [/i]

I was just looking for a story somewhere. I played for 40 minutes and I feel like they gave us nothing meaningful. I know there's some kind of mind control thing but that's it. So if it doesn't use story to drive engagement then it must be using excellent platforming mechanics since the art and music is described as "dark and moody" (not a plus in my book), right?

No.

The character feels about as good at running and jumping as you expect and somewhat better than expected at falling (slightly longer falls still insta kill you though). The puzzles weren't too bad, but a little hard to figure out at times while generally easy to execute. I prefer easier to figure out the answer and harder to execute for platformer games.

Over all I would say I was just bored, bored, bored! Boring story, boring graphics and music, boring platforming. I need at least one of those categories to interest me if you want more than half an hour of my time.

139510475.review:
I'll be real... I didn't enjoy this game. 

You know what I did enjoy, back in 2010? A little indie game called Limbo. It was a simplistic, shorter game in which you played a scared little child running left to right in foreboding, shadow-silhouetted environments. It had a control scheme that only used a few buttons,  a minimalist soundtrack, and a pretty much non-existent story sprinkled with hints of pretentiousness.  You spent the first thirty or so minutes fleeing a giant demon-spider, followed by two hours of traipsing through dull, boring, insipid, ruined warehouses and factories. Honestly, if you stopped after the demon-spider died, you did yourself a favor. Oh, and every death animation was brutal and cruel. Said animations shocked you the first couple of times, but then lost all meaning as desensitization kicked in. 

Limbo pretty much kicked off the "scared child in spooky nightmare land" indie genre. A seemingly endless litany of similar indie games followed in its wake, each slightly more tedious than the last. Almost none reached the lofty heights that Limbo did with its freaky-deaky giant demon-spider. 

So what did Limbo's developers do to follow up their success? This game, which would have been more aptly titled Limbo 1.5. You're still a little kid, running left to right in a big, bad world. Only, there's no demon spider hunting you through a big pine forest for thirty minutes. Instead, you run from some blokes and their dogs as they chase you across a small patch of forest and some corn fields. Then, the obligatory two plus hours of run-down, dimly lit, gray-colored warehouses, factories, and research facilities kick in. It's dull. Exceedingly dull, and the muted sounds and minimalist soundtrack DO NOT HELP MATTERS. On the plus side, the last ten minutes of the game veer wildly into a psychotic, non-sequitur blob sequence that makes no sense whatsoever, but feels like a generous reprieve from the afore-mentioned tedium. 

It just did not work for me. The deaths lost all impact ten minutes in. The level variety left a lot to be desired. The story was non-existent and abysmally shallow (though that hasn't stopped hardcore fans from filling in the massive blanks with their empty conjectures and pseudo-theories). I was checking my timer 20 minutes in and praying that the game would end soon. Never crashed, ran fine, and seemed polished. Just not my cup of tea. This genre is clearly not for me. 

But... if you're a fan of this genre, here's another one of them. It's made by the people who put this genre on the map, so you're going to get what you're looking for. If you're not a fan, I might recommend Limbo instead. Same developers, same ambiance, similar control scheme, and same general polish. It sells for a fairly low price nowadays and the first thirty minutes with the giant demon-spider are wonderful. Tense, freaky, and off-putting. Again, just make sure to stop immediately after you have bested the eight legged terror.  You'll have seen the best this genre has to offer and can move on.

Title: INSIDE: A Hauntingly Atmospheric and Thought-Provoking Journey

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

INSIDE, the enigmatic puzzle-platformer developed by Playdead, is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling and immersive gameplay. With its haunting visuals, atmospheric sound design, and thought-provoking narrative, INSIDE delivers a captivating and unforgettable experience that pushes the boundaries of the genre.

One of the most striking aspects of INSIDE is its visual design. The game's dark and atmospheric environments, rendered in minimalist yet highly detailed graphics, create a sense of unease and mystery. The use of light and shadow, combined with subtle animations and seamless transitions, adds depth and immersion to every scene. The visuals work in perfect harmony with the game's narrative, unraveling its dark secrets and unveiling a dystopian world filled with sinister undertones.

The sound design in INSIDE is equally remarkable. The haunting ambient sounds, eerie melodies, and atmospheric effects contribute to the game's oppressive atmosphere, heightening the sense of tension and unease. The lack of traditional dialogue or exposition allows the player to immerse themselves fully in the experience, interpreting the story through visual and auditory cues, deepening the sense of mystery and intrigue.

The gameplay mechanics of INSIDE are simple yet ingeniously designed. As the protagonist, players navigate through a series of challenging puzzles and platforming sequences, utilizing the environment and manipulating objects to progress. The puzzles gradually increase in complexity, requiring keen observation and experimentation to overcome. The fluid controls and intuitive mechanics make for a smooth and satisfying gameplay experience, ensuring that the focus remains on the exploration and the unraveling of the narrative.

The narrative of INSIDE is a masterpiece in subtlety and ambiguity. It slowly unveils a thought-provoking and metaphorical tale, inviting players to interpret its meaning and symbolism. The game's deliberate pacing and meticulously crafted set pieces create an unsettling and mesmerizing narrative arc that leaves a lasting impact. The lack of explicit exposition allows for personal interpretation, making each playthrough a unique and introspective experience.

INSIDE's concise but profound storytelling is complemented by its impeccable pacing. The game masterfully balances moments of tension and quiet introspection, providing a captivating rhythm that keeps players engaged from start to finish. The gradual reveal of the world's secrets and the protagonist's journey through various environments create a sense of wonder and curiosity, propelling the player forward.

While INSIDE's brevity may be seen as a drawback by some, the game's concise length is a testament to its focus and artistic integrity. It is a tightly woven experience, leaving a lasting impact in its relatively short playtime.

In conclusion, INSIDE is an atmospheric and thought-provoking masterpiece. With its haunting visuals, immersive sound design, and enigmatic narrative, the game invites players on a deeply introspective and emotionally charged journey. It's a testament to the power of minimalist storytelling and atmospheric gameplay. INSIDE is an experience that lingers long after the credits roll, leaving players contemplating its profound themes and imagery. For those seeking a unique and evocative gaming experience, INSIDE is an absolute must-play.

This game is dripping with atmosphere, every fifteen minutes had some fresh horror making me ask “What in Satan’s unholy butthole is that?”. Unfortunately, that’s about all this game has. The puzzles are simple and for a ‘platformer’ it doesn’t have a whole lot of platforms. The world is like a subway tunnel, too cramped to explore in any direction but one, and the ‘story’ is just a collection of creepy vibes linked by nothing but blank spaces that the player can choose to fill with whatever they want. Is atmosphere enough to make a game? I think that depends on the player, I enjoyed it, but if you’re looking for something with a little more substance to it, a narrative or a challenge, then this is probably not the game for you. 139128307.review:
A short but enjoyable game for sure.  Inside has you control a boy who seems to be running from the dystopian world that surrounds him.  Either the humanoids that he meets on his journey are slumped or under some type of control, sometimes yours, or they are after you knowing that you are not conforming to the rest that are slumped or under control.

Inside plays as a simple 2.5D platforming game with puzzles to help you move along the continuous level.  The games lasts about 4 hours, all while dodging enemy humanoid, dogs, and robots.  In order to solve puzzles you can control other enslaved humanoids to help you move heavy items, throw you to hard to reach areas, and more.

The palette for Inside is rather dark, not as much contrast as Limbo, there original game, but still quite a dark palette nonethless.  The main character is what has the most colors, everything else is a different type of grayish type of color.  This makes for quite a somber atmosphere which fits well in the Orwellian world that you journey through.

There was nothing difficult in this game that can't be figured out after 2-3 tries in the most difficult of areas, but the unnarrated story of the world you experience mixed with the smooth animated characters movement makes for a satisfying game to play.  The graphics are quite good.  The water effects of your every step, the bending of the boards as you cross over empty spaces, all add to a believable world that you are running around in.  The devs did a good job of the added details in the graphics and animations and really used lighting to its best of effects here.

The music matches the graphics, simple, somber, and dark while the sounds work well whether driving around in a submarine, or hearing the grunts of control humanoids falling off a high platform.  Overall everything matches well together to create a good sense of immersion.

You can easily play this game in one playthrough as I did, it is that good and that short.  No matter the length, I enjoy a game that provides all it can give and not stretch it out just by adding fluff, this game was perfectly paces and perfectly designed for levels that would increasingly be difficult, but not so difficult as to stump you.  If you get the chance, check this game out, I'm certain that you can get it for a great price, especially during some great sales.  Can't wait till Playdead's next game.

a general note about interpreting reviews: games on steam which offer demos will have boosted ratings for two reasons. 1) only steam users who own a game can review it. 2) if a demo is offered for the game then there is a higher proportion of people buying the game who *already know* they like it, as well as a higher proportion of people who don't like the game that the demo filters *out* from buying the game (and therefore filters out from the review process). this shouldn't bother you since you can simply ignore the reviews and play the demo for yourself, but it's worth pointing out.

This is excellent, I loved it!
A short, dark, mysterious, side scrolling puzzle platformer, with a really good story line, amazing art style and sound effects. It's storyline is horror/sci-fi/thriller/suspense .

There's no dialogue, back story or any lead in to the game, it just starts and your alone stumbling down a dark forest. You run, and you keep running, not knowing who or what you are running from, who you are or why you are running. You just know you can't let anyone catch and kill you!

You hide out of sight briefly when you can't run and there are a few cases where timing is important to avoid enemies, and the use of moving objects is required to solve small puzzles and navigate around enemies or progress further in the story. The game always keeps moving and can be completed in 3 and half hours.

Although you don't know anything about the story, the intrigue is there and mystery of what has happened in this world - dead pigs, a derelict world, civilians marching as if controlled, and you, just a boy running - is this a war, a plague, a famine, some sort of invasion? 

You'll speculate what it all means, who you are and where you are running to, what's going to happen next, and right up until the end couldn't wait to see how the story was going to unfold.
Played it through in one sitting. It was that good!

I could even see this being a comic book or cartoon, the style and story was amazing that it didn't even bother me that there was no dialogue from the characters.

Would play it again, and again.

10/10

138376503.review:
A pretty great li'l puzzle platformer that stands out with its presentation and creativity, and is otherwised saved from being a tad cliche it's MADNESS-riddled ending.

GOOD STUFF:
+ Art style and graphics are great to look at and really convey a mood. Could maybe have used a TOUCH more color.
+ Most puzzles are tough enough to be satisfying, but even a tard like me didn't need a walkthrough. They all make sense and while they're very unique and diverse, they will probably be approachable if you apply logic from other video games.
+ There's a real relishable weight to the movement and momentum. The player character has so many subtle little twitches and animations to interact with what's currently going on, and he usually feels good to control. The way your lobotomized followers bumble and crash around is fun to watch.
+ Gameplay keeps changing itself to give you fresh new interactions. There's a submarine section that was particularly fun.
+ Soundwork is great. Very minimal score, which suits the game. Foley work is very creepy, visceral, and great.
+ The death/failure animations don't hold back. When the protagonist dies, he gets f*cking killed.
+ A reasonably interesting story is told purely through the environment. I could have used maybe 20% less vagueness about some parts though.
+ There seemed to be sort of a hackneyed dystopia element to the narrative at first especially being a vulnerable little boy in red running away from the industrialized, scary world... but that's revealed not to entirely be the case, and the final 1/4 of the game comes out of absolute nowhere and I feel cements this game's high reputation. It's not just a narrative reveal, it affects the rest of the gameplay too.

BAD STUFF:
- I really don't like to rate games by "dollars per hour," but $20 is just way too much. It's one linear campaign that took me 3 hours, and nothing else besides some achievements. I think I got this for like $6 or something. Wait for a sale.
- A couple puzzles were pretty oblique in their methodology, wherein a couple I got lucky from guesses and a couple more I tried the correct solution 2 or 3 times before it actually went through. 
- The complex physics and momentum don't always follow your inputs as well as they should. I screwed up the puzzles and died a handful of times because of this. This can be extra finicky in the otherwise great ending segment.

Great game. I've played these critically lauded 2D platformers before like Limbo and Braid, and didn't really find them super fun or impressive for someone not that into the genre. For a few bucks, it's worth your time for sure.

This game left me satisfied with it's conclusion, although this is to no surprise as I loved INSIDE's predecessor Limbo when I was younger. I absolutely don't regret trying INSIDE, and I look forward to any future works by Playdead studios.

Having recently completed "Inside" and devoting a solid five hours to secure all achievements, I can confidently declare that this game is a masterstroke in contemporary gaming. The amalgamation of the ambient music and top-notch sound design is simply unparalleled, creating an otherworldly gaming experience that is immersive in ways few other games can claim.

One of the captivating aspects is the game's refined controls. They are intuitive and silky smooth, allowing for the utmost immersion and engagement within the game's environment. The interaction with the surroundings feels impressively organic, almost blurring the line between the virtual and real world.

The visual design adheres to a minimalist aesthetic, which might seem simple at first glance, but offers a rich atmosphere and stunning use of colors that is as engaging as it is stylistic. The story unfolds in a compelling way, without a single line of dialogue.

From the moment I started playing, I was hooked. I found it almost impossible to put down until I had seen it through to the end. Each puzzle presented in the game was intriguing and didn't feel like a rehashed version of something I'd seen before. Every moment of the gameplay was enjoyable and managed to keep me engaged, making it a truly unique experience that I haven't encountered in ages.

In conclusion, "Inside" is an exceptional gaming experience that I cannot recommend highly enough. It is an amazing blend of atmospheric music, unique storytelling, and intuitive gameplay. This game is a must-play for anyone looking for a fresh, engaging, and rewarding experience.

138087826.review:
Inside is a 2.5D puzzle-platformer by Playdead, and it continues their tradition of having a unique look, a colored, low-poly artstyle this time. You play as a boy who is hunted by government agents. After running through dystopian streets filled with mindless people and empty fields, he would have to cross a mysterious research facility. It does raise the question, is this facility simply on the way, or does he have a greater mission? 

Story plays an important part, in fact this game is more story-based and less puzzle-platformer than its predecessor Limbo. The puzzles here feel natural, like how you must use the items around you to progress, instead of being puzzles for the sake of puzzles. For example, in some parts you can gather mindless people to progress. You can lead them and with their help, move heavy objects or reach higher ledges. There's no annoying precision platforming such as "jump down the slide at the right time to reach next platform and avoid these unnaturally large saws". And while timing-reliant stuff still exists, the timing is a lot more forgiving.

The level variation is another good thing, there are many, but they also feel real and natural. There are forests, farms, flooded labs, mines, etc. The enemy encounters, which are my favorite parts of Limbo, are also more common here and are fun to dealt with, like hiding from guards and running from dogs. It reminds me more of Little Nightmares, another great puzzle-platformer with a creepy atmosphere. There are also collectibles, don't forget to seek these mysterious orbs out for achievements and an alternate ending that might make things a bit clearer... even though its still confusing.

Overall, I think Inside is a major improvement from Limbo, which to be honest I don't really like. The most important thing is that its easier and more story-based rather than puzzle-platforming, I never felt frustrated during my whole run. If you enjoy puzzle-platformers and story-based games you will have a great time with this title. 138009038.review:
[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay is perfect for what someone may expect from a game of the genre, a 2d platform sidescroller seems quite an accurate description for this piece. I had quite a lot of fun trying to figure out the solutions to the problems and obstacles found along the way. It is not a frenetic experiencie, it is not a guns blazin' experience, it is a puzzle game with some platorming and sidcrolling within it. [u]If you are looking for an assasins creed or a call of duty, this may not be your game.[/u]

[h1]Controls:[/h1]
This game has the simplest control configuration I have had the pleasure to deal with in a very long time. Only 6 buttons are required to play this game, up down left right and 'A' for grabbing or interacting and 'B' for jumping, almost reminds of the old NES and Gameboy games. This sentence alone should let readers know about the implicit simplicity of the mechanics you shall encounter in this game. Although do not be missguided into thinking that the game is boring.

[h1]Atmosphere:[/h1]
This is one of the strong points of the game, the atmosphere is well developed and established although probably not the main focus of the game as it would be in a horror title. It sets the mood rather well for the environment it all happens in and is a piece of added flavour to the game.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
This game is for the kind of player that likes to observe, theorize and reflect upon what is seen, constantly, because nothing will ever be said nor directly implied. The lore of the game seems to be a big question mark and that may be a very good choice for this game, although I like to have my anwsers figured out, this game does a marvelous job in delivering a story masked as 'almost nothing really'. It does that in a way that creates questions, constantly, that drives the player forward for answers that only bring more questions.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
The graphics are one of the positives aspects of the game. Although in many parts of the game the graphics and scene become extremely dark and you may want to increase your brightness against that. I loved the artistic style, it is very nicely executed, but it is quite a saddening thing that it was not more extensively explored within vivid colours. One may argue that for the sake of the atmosphere there could not be many vibrant tones, but being almost monocromatic, at times, may risk being repetitive, Nontheless, I truly enjoyed the graphics, the 'flaw' I mentioned, seemes to have had a purpose.

[h1]replayability[/h1]
Close to zero to be completely honest.
I only mention this because of the alternate ending. To find it, it had me go through the game again, and look for the pieces of the game that i had missed the first run. Otherwise there is no replayability whatsoever,
unless you want to figure out the story for yourself and theorize about what happened within the game universe. Also, good F***ing luck finding those collectibles you need for the alternate ending, there is one specific piece that had me sweat for a big while, then jump to google due to my frustration. Also, there is one specific puzzle, always within the replayability context, that i would have never figured out on my own, my low IQ may be showing here, but a little hint may be good for players. Feels like they expected people to google stuff out [spoiler] Me being salty [/spoiler].

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
I truly enjoyed the game. Bought it for 2€ and got 30 hours worth of fun. Passing around the controller when getting stuck was a nice experience with my wife. The type of gameplay, rather relaxing and head-scratch inducing, sometimes, turned up the speed and had you go in some sort of more action-like gameplay moments at others. Alltogether, the story, the atmosphere, the gameplay, simpliciy and pace resulted in a well developet product that deserves praise. Super-recommended!

137995454.review:
I genuinely loved this game; through every development and turn, it kept me invested and intrigued. This, alone, is a huge reason as to why I like this game so much. INSIDE is clever with its puzzles, has fantastic escape sequences, it's unapologetic and gruesome. Even the narrative alone is this depressing, dark, wicked, incredibly-interesting yet terrifically-done tale on Class and Human Testing. (Of which, sadly I will not go into due to spoilers.) In summary - it's incredibly well made.

In large, the world-building is phenomenal - every scene means something and Playdead makes anything you may go through count. Watching the sleepwalkers mark in unison, realising what is happening in the factories and other places alike. It's disturbing but once again, so, so interesting. Especially on your first play-through. The puzzles are also fantastic. (As you would expect from a puzzle game.) They fit the world perfectly and it even 1-ups Playdeads previous game, LIMBO. INSIDE does what LIMBO did but just better; the lack of UI. Though, with INSIDE, it's cleaner and polished. The intricate use of colour design makes the experience as a whole even better. It clues you in better - it's straightforward as to what you can interact with but by no means does it give the puzzle away entirely. Plus, it's worth noting, how that when you mess up a puzzle, you can tell where you went wrong. Did I just get torn to shreds by one of the dogs? Okay, maybe I should've been more patient. Stuff like that.

Another large aspect I like about this game is just how well it flows. Going smoothly from one environment to another - gives you a large range of puzzles without it seeming abrupt or forced. It's honestly great. And, it's in this regard, that INSIDE's visual style and design are just on another level entirely. The enemies appear and you deal with them, and even how they progress and change throughout the game too is beyond amazing. It's such a simple concept when put like that but something INSIDE nails. Something I will quickly mention though (it's a part of the trailer so no spoilers here) - the sequence where you have to blend in with the sleepwalkers felt fantastic with the game's flow. It was unexpected but you just have to go with it knowing that one wrong move and you're a goner again. It happens but it's not abrupt. Again, something this game nails. Even despite it being one of the most straightforward parts of the game it's incredibly nerve-wracking. 

Something I feel isn't mentioned enough though is this game's sound design. Every noise and crack and bang is finely tuned to immerse you further into the experience. The dogs barking, the jostling of a chain fence, it's silent when it needs to be, loud bangs fit, the no dialogue - all uninterrupted. 

In conclusion, there are no UI prompts, no minimaps, no score, no timer, and no health or stamina bar - it's immersive and incredibly interesting. As much as I love the narrative of INSIDE and as much as I would love to see it more - it's something that shouldn't be replicated or copied. I'm glad INSIDE has its own, unique story and especially in the way it's presented to you. I just wish other video games learnt from this sort of storytelling.

Excellent. This game is almost a spiritual successor to Limbo, created by the same team, and it improves upon the idea's, visuals and sounds of Limbo in every way.

The atmosphere created in Inside is simply awesome. You are drawn into a world that is filled with tensity and ever impending dread, as you try desperately to escape terrors, and just manage to by the skin of your teeth.

The sound and visuals of the game are breathtaking at times, and the soundtrack will leave you well and truly immersed.

There is an ongoing theme of escape throughout the game and it has a good storyline that gives away just enough for you to understand the general plot, but leaves enough ambiguity for you to question certain things and fill in the blanks using your own imagination.

The gameplay itself is fun and progresses nicely. The puzzle's aren't too difficult but they are very creative so they're still fun and don't feel repetitive.

The games has some nice secrets that are fun to discover and solve, and lead to a secret ending.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed Limbo or any similar puzzle game.

137784543.review: Playdead Studios first knocked my socks off with thriller puzzle game-play with it's ingenious game 'Limbo.' Hinting at a story line ever so quietly as you navigate what the title suggests is it's namesake, a mirrored world between the spiritual one and the living. It was left to my interpretation by the end of 'Limbo' and left me theorizing for weeks about it's strange nature. Then, just the other day, I discovered yet another Playdead horror puzzle masterpiece- 'Inside.' 'Inside' spits you into a world that seems to parallel the one in 'Limbo' in many ways, the hint going so far as to shove a giant fallen neon 'E' letter right in your face as you explore a city not unlike the one in limbo- An 'E' that is seen as part of a 'HOTEL' sign in 'Inside's' sister game. With unlock-able achievements and thrilling puzzles and more hints at lore than I could have ever asked for, Inside is sure to leave me re-examining my theories on 'Limbo' and forming new ones from 'Inside' for weeks. The ending was ambiguous enough to leave anyone stumbling over theories- and it's hidden alternate ending hints towards some more than others. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves science fiction, dystopian thriller/horror games, and to anyone who can stomach a few notable less than savory levels. And of course, anyone with a good brain on them who loves a good puzzle, all of them thinkers, and plenty of stumpers that make you go 'a-ha!' Once you get them. I haven't been this impresssed with a puzzle game since Limbo and I can't wait to see more from the Geniuses behind Playdead. I'll certainly be looking into any other projects of theirs I may have missed!
